title: Between 1815 and 1845 the population of Germany (excluding Austria) grew from 25 to 34.5 million. The German governments were alarmed, and Malthus’ predictions about the dire consequences of a multiplying population prompted some of them, chiefly in southern and central Germany, to issue laws making marriages contingent on a means test. These rather ineffective laws, some of which were abolished only after 1867, were signs of prevailing doubts about the chances for an expansion of the economy, and optimism was certainly ill-founded [for] Germany lacked the capital required for any large-scale development
